content.body: sideshowbarker: Does MDN document the autoboxing of primitives anywhere? I’m writing up documentation on why `x = 3; x.p = 2` doesn’t actually assign anything, and I’d like to be able to link to somewhere that explains, “The `3` gets autoboxed into a Number object that then gets discarded.”

content.body: it's probably worth having such documentation, but in real life people should use strict mode so that `x.p = 2` is an error and they don't have to think about it

content.body: it does; see GetValue step 4.a: https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/ecmascript-data-types-and-values.html#sec-getvalue

I’m writing beginner documentation about `obj.prop = val` that mentions this idiosyncrasy and says, “Don’t do this,” but maybe I should just avoid mentioning it at all for now. MDN doesn’t talk about primitives in its tutorial until its “Advanced” level.
content.formatted_body: I’m writing beginner documentation about obj.prop = val that mentions this idiosyncrasy and says, “Don’t do this,” but maybe I should just avoid mentioning it at all for now. MDN doesn’t talk about primitives in its tutorial until its “Advanced” level.

content.body: or I guess PutValue 5.a., rather: https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/ecmascript-data-types-and-values.html#sec-putvalue

PutValue is invoked in step 1.e. of the evaluation semantics for assignment: https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/ecmascript-language-expressions.html#sec-assignment-operators-runtime-semantics-evaluation

`Object("").prop = 1` OK

content.body: Ashley Claymore: only in strict mode!
content.formatted_body: Ashley Claymore: only in strict mode!

content.body: jschoi: I would encourage telling beginners to only ever write or think about strict mode code, and to avoid telling them things which are only relevant to sloppy mode
content.formatted_body: jschoi: I would encourage telling beginners to only ever write or think about strict mode code, and to avoid telling them things which are only relevant to sloppy mode

content.body: Right, if set returns false it only throws in strict.
What I mean is you get a different behaviour between auto-box and explicit box
content.formatted_body: What I mean is you get a different behaviour between auto-box and explicit box

content.body: the auto-box acts like it’s non-extensible, but the actual box is extensible
content.formatted_body: the auto-box acts like it’s non-extensible, but the actual box is extensible

content.body: it's... actually weirder than that
Can ECMA262 have a tagline?
`'use strict'; Object.defineProperty(Number.prototype, 'x', { set: () => { console.log(this) } }); (3).x = 2; // works!`
content.formatted_body: 'use strict'; Object.defineProperty(Number.prototype, 'x', { set: () => { console.log(this) } }); (3).x = 2; // works!

content.body: it's not that the auto-box acts like it's non-extensible, it's that in strict mode the [[Set]] sees the target as the primitive, rather than as the box, which is observable with setters

In sloppy mode `this` gets converted to object, so `PutValue` operates on the boxed version, and ToObject simply returns the already boxed value
In strict mode, the value stays a primitive, ToObject boxes it, so `set` is given the primitive as receiver, which it checks, and throws
content.formatted_body:
In sloppy mode this gets converted to object, so PutValue operates on the boxed version, and ToObject simply returns the already boxed value
In strict mode, the value stays a primitive, ToObject boxes it, so set is given the primitive as receiver, which it checks, and throws

content.body: `Reflect.set(Object(3), 'x', 2, 3)` vs `tmp = Object(3); Reflect.set(tmp, 'x', 2, tmp)`
content.formatted_body: Reflect.set(Object(3), 'x', 2, 3) vs tmp = Object(3); Reflect.set(tmp, 'x', 2, tmp)

content.body: * `Reflect.set(Object(3), 'x', 2, 3)` vs `tmp = Object(3); Reflect.set(tmp, 'x', 2, tmp)`
content.formatted_body: * Reflect.set(Object(3), 'x', 2, 3) vs tmp = Object(3); Reflect.set(tmp, 'x', 2, tmp)
